Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Situation2: A patient with a common illness like strep throat has come to the clinic for a check-up.
Story: I glance at my phone between patients, my heart sinking as I read the text from Alex: “I thought we were spending Saturday together. Why didn’t you tell me about your shift?” I can sense the disappointment behind his words, and I know I should call him, clear up the misunderstanding before it festers. But just then, the nurse knocks and ushers in my next patient—a teenager with a sore throat, fever, and worried mother in tow. I slip on my professional mask, listen to symptoms, and prepare to examine her, all the while my mind tugs back to Alex. He expects me to be present, to resolve our conflict with reassurance and honesty. My patient expects me to focus, to diagnose and prescribe the right treatment. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my full attention, and I can’t help but wonder which part of me I’ll have to let down, even if just for a moment.
